author: By Sam Sifton
title: This ‘Fake Sauce’ Is Truly Good
description: For your Sunday supper: hearty pasta al sugo finto, a vegetarian ragù that’s flavorful and frugal.
content: Good morning. There’s a term in Italian cooking, cucina povera. It translates literally as “kitchen of the poor,” but in practice means the kitchen of the frugal, the cooking of the thrifty and unwasteful. I think of it, myself, as the cuisine of the empty nester, of the dope who once again forgot to pick up sausages during the weekly shop, who doesn’t have a pound of ground beef in the freezer, who arrives at Sunday afternoon with only a decent pantry and a bunch of oldish vegetables in the crisper.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: John F. Kennedy Jr.’s 1990s-Era Magazine Is Back, With a QAnon Twist
description: It is a reanimation story strange enough for a zombie movie, made possible by the fact that the original George trademark lapsed, only to be secured by a conservative lawyer.
content: On a Saturday morning in August, a few hundred people gathered at a convention center in Hot Springs, Ark., paying between $145 and $475 to hear from a cast of far-right speakers. They included a body builder-turned-pundit who carries a tomahawk and promotes an antisemitic conspiracy theory, and a pro-Trump preacher who has warned of threats posed by technologically sophisticated demon mermaids.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Roy
title: Who Is That You Are Chatting With? Oh, Just ChatGPT.
description: The artificial intelligence chatbot’s Advanced Voice Mode feature has delighted some users and weirded out others.
content: When you think of what a voice programmed by artificial intelligence would sound like, you might picture something robotic and stilted, with a staccato cadence incapable of capturing the inflections, speed and emotion required to sound even somewhat human. But this is 2024, and the robots have gotten a serious upgrade. Now they can imitate voices, accents and intonation to an almost creepy degree — for better or worse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Burdick and Katrina Miller
title: A Shift in the World of Science
description: What this year’s Nobels can teach us about science and humanity.
content: Technology observers have grown increasingly vocal in recent years about the threat that artificial intelligence poses to the human variety. A.I. models can write and talk like us, draw and paint like us, crush us at chess and Go. They express an unnerving simulacrum of creativity, not least where the truth is concerned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Varenikova
title: Russian Strikes on Ukrainian Ports Target Civilian Shipping
description: With the strikes in the Odesa region, Russia appears to be trying again to prevent Ukraine from exporting grain, harming its economy and pushing up world prices.
content: Russia has stepped up its assaults on Black Sea port infrastructure and civilian shipping in recent days, in what Ukraine says is an attempt to disrupt its exports and damage its economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 491
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, Oct. 14, 2024.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich
title: Can the Government Get People to Have More Babies?
description: Japan has been trying to boost its fertility rate for 30 years. Now the rest of the rich world is, too.
content: In 1989, Japan seemed to be an unstoppable economic superpower. Its companies were overtaking competitors and gobbling up American icons like Rockefeller Center. But inside the country, the government had identified a looming, slow-motion crisis: The fertility rate had fallen to a record low. Policymakers called it the “1.57 shock,” citing the projected average number of children that women would have over their childbearing years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Isabel Webb
title: Can We Please Just Find the Aliens Already?
description: NASA’s Europa Clipper mission represents something bigger than just the study of an icy moon of Jupiter.
content: Picture an ice-covered landscape, rough and rocky. Plumes of water vapor erupt from the surface. Tendrils of algae lurk in the bright white glaciers. Deep below the surface, microorganisms and other creatures cluster near hydrothermal vents, fissures in the ocean floor where life can thrive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas and Maya King
title: Harris Suggests Trump Is ‘Weak and Unstable’ in Pointed Challenge
description: Kamala Harris asked why Donald J. Trump had not released his medical records, appeared on “60 Minutes” or agreed to a second debate.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris challenged former President Donald J. Trump on Sunday for refusing to do what she has done in recent days: release a report on his health, sit for a “60 Minutes” interview and commit to another presidential debate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Farrell
title: The Secretive Dynasty That Controls the Boar’s Head Brand
description: The deli-meat company made its owners fabulously wealthy. But they have remained silent, even as the company faces the biggest scandal in its history.
content: In May 2022, the chief financial officer of Boar’s Head, the processed meat company, was asked a simple question under oath.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper
title: U.S. to Deploy Missile Defense System and About 100 Troops to Israel
description: The Pentagon announced it would send the Terminal High Altitude Area Defense battery and its crew as Israel considered retaliatory attacks against Iran.
content: The United States is sending an advanced missile defense system to Israel, along with about 100 American troops to operate it, the Pentagon announced on Sunday. It is the first deployment of U.S. forces to Israel since the Hamas-led attacks there on Oct. 7, 2023.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Trump Hits Coachella, Campaigning Once Again in a Blue State
description: The former president took a detour from the battleground states to hold a rally in the California desert, where temperatures hovered near 100 degrees.
content: Both presidential campaigns agree that seven swing states are likely to determine the outcome of this year’s election. California, which has not voted for a Republican in a presidential race since 1988, is not one of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: 50 Years of Broccoli (and Mockery): A Co-op Co-Founder Calls It Quits
description: In 1973, Joe Holtz helped start the Park Slope Food Co-op, a Brooklyn institution that is equally loved and ridiculed. Will it survive his retirement?
content: For a 74-year-old, Joe Holtz can cover a lot of ground very quickly. The ground he was covering the other day was the three adjoining carriage houses in Brooklyn that were subsumed by the Park Slope Food Co-op as it grew and became the largest, busiest and most argument-inducing single-store food cooperative in the United States. Every square foot, in the breakneck tour he gave, reminded him of an episode in the store’s history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Fisher-Price Recalls 2 Million ‘Snuga Swings’ After Five Infant Deaths
description: The U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission announced the recall, which one of its commissioners said was “doomed to fail.”
content: After at least five infants died while sleeping in a product made by Fisher-Price, the company has recalled more than two million of the product, the Snuga Swing, because it poses a suffocation risk, according to the recall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,213
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, Oct. 14, 2024.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anupreeta Das and Hari Kumar
title: Ladakh’s Local Hero Wants India to Pay Attention to His People
description: The activist Sonam Wangchuk is leading protests to demand more autonomy for India’s remote Ladakh region, which shares borders with China and Pakistan.
content: Sonam Wangchuk has worn many hats: as an engineer, an environmentalist and an education reformer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang and Eric Lipton
title: SpaceX Advances Starship Program With a Launch and a Catch
description: The company completed a successful test flight of the most powerful rocket ever built. Some residents near the Texas site experienced shaking as the landing vehicle was caught by mechanical arms.
content: SpaceX pulled off a feat of technical wizardry on Sunday, not only flying a 233-foot rocket booster back to its launch site, but also catching it out of the air with two giant mechanical arms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Root, Bianca Pallaro, Emma G. Fitzsimmons, Michael Forsythe and Karina Tsui
title: She Was a Key Aide to Eric Adams. Her Ties to China Ran Deep.
description: Winnie Greco, a top fund-raiser and senior adviser for Mr. Adams, has long had dealings with people and groups connected to China’s communist regime. He kept her close even so.
content: Mayor Eric Adams was riding high in the fall of 2022 when Winnie Greco, one of his best fund-raisers and a top adviser, led him into a glittering ballroom in Flushing, Queens, the heart of the Chinese diaspora in New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: One Who Walks the Walk
description: Dana Edwards makes his New York Times Crossword debut, and it’s a slam dunk.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Just Over the Border from Israel, a Hezbollah Cache of Explosives and Mines
description: Israel’s military showed journalists parts of what it said was Hezbollah’s deeply entrenched military infrastructure across the border in southern Lebanon.
content: We had entered southern Lebanon early Sunday afternoon in a convoy of armored vehicles through a gap punched by Israeli forces in the snaking border wall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Harris Sends a Secret Weapon to a Georgia Fish Fry: Bill Clinton
description: With early voting set to begin in Georgia, the Harris campaign is sending the former president to get out the vote in rural areas.
content: The smell of fried fish was lingering on Sunday afternoon, and there was Bill Clinton beneath a tree, wearing a Harris-Walz camouflage cap and edging closer and closer to his modest audience the longer he spoke.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: The Painter Titus Kaphar Wanted a Bigger Canvas, So He Made a Film
description: His first feature, “Exhibiting Forgiveness,” which opens Oct. 18, features paintings now on view at Gagosian in Los Angeles.
content: We often scrutinize an artist’s work, searching for autobiographical clues. But in Titus Kaphar’s recent paintings, and in his new film, “Exhibiting Forgiveness,” such close reading is unnecessary. His life experience is laid bare, in all its poignant and — sometimes agonizing — pain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mara Gay
title: New York Can Do Better Than Andrew Cuomo
description: Democrats should make it clear that Cuomo has no political future in New York — not in City Hall and not in Albany.
content: There are many ways for New York City to turn the page on Mayor Eric Adams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina, Ruth Igielnik and Jazmine Ulloa
title: Harris Struggles to Win Over Latinos, While Trump Holds His Grip, Poll Shows
description: Latino voters said they were open to Donald J. Trump’s immigration policies and hungry for change. Many remain undecided.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris’s support among Hispanic voters is in dangerously low territory for Democrats, according to a New York Times/Siena College poll, while her rival, former President Donald J. Trump, has maintained his strength with the fast-growing group poised to play a key role in deciding control of the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Abdul Salaam, Quiet Member of the Jets’ ‘Sack Exchange,’ Dies at 71
description: A defensive tackle, he teamed with Joe Klecko, Mark Gastineau and Marty Lyons in the 1980s on a line that terrorized quarterbacks.
content: Abdul Salaam, an unassuming but important member of the ferocious Jets defensive line, known as the New York Sack Exchange, that preyed on quarterbacks in the 1980s, died on Tuesday in Cincinnati. He was 71.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Barker
title: Jokes and Offbeat Auctions for the Troops: Standup Comedy Sweeps Ukraine
description: Even as the conflict with Russia grinds on, a new generation of comics in Ukraine is trying to make people laugh — and raise money for the war effort.
content: Onstage in a Kyiv theater, Anton Tymoshenko tells a joke about Ukrainians who are never satisfied with the weapons their country gets from the West — if they got nuclear weapons, he says, they would probably grumble about the quality of the uranium. He mocks the Odesa mayor (for being allegedly pro-Russian) and the Kyiv one (for being allegedly pro-himself).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: On ‘S.N.L.,’ Harris and Trump Take Their Contest to ‘Family Feud’
description: It was also an especially music-filled evening, with Stevie Nicks as the musical guest and Ariana Grande, as host, breaking often into song.
content: Although former President Donald J. Trump refused invitations for a second debate with Vice President Kamala Harris, “Saturday Night Live” came up with another setting where both presidential nominees might share the stage: the game show “Family Feud.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Oct. 13, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Oct. 13, 2024.
content: An article last Sunday about the growth of the “SmartLess” podcast misspelled the surname of the CAA executive who helped expand the podcast’s brand. He is Josh Lindgen, not Lingen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlos Lozada
title: When Trump Rants, This Is What I Hear
description: His hostility has taught me more about myself.
content: I’ve never considered “immigrant” my calling card, even though it’s one I’ve always carried.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Can the New York Liberty, the Best in the W.N.B.A, Finally Win It All?
description: The Liberty, an original W.N.B.A. franchise, have been to the finals five times and lost each time. But their fans can’t help believing, again, this year.
content: Barclays Center in Brooklyn shook with the roar of 17,700 basketball fans, almost all of them rooting for the New York Liberty. They have been waiting years for a team like this one, and on Thursday, with only five minutes left and the Liberty up by 15 points over the Minnesota Lynx in Game 1 of the W.N.B.A. finals, there was a sense that the team’s run of failures was going to be over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Woman Who Tried to Smuggle 29 Turtles Wrapped in Socks Pleads Guilty
description: A resident of Hong Kong was caught while paddling across a lake from Vermont to Canada in an inflatable kayak with the Eastern box turtles in a duffle bag, according to court records.
content: A woman pleaded guilty on Friday to attempting to smuggle 29 Eastern box turtles, a protected species, that were individually wrapped in socks inside a duffle bag as she tried to paddle in an inflatable kayak across a lake from Vermont to Canada over the summer, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katelyn Ferral
title: After Hurricane Milton Left, My Town Revealed Itself
description: I had only recently moved to Tampa and before the storm didn’t feel connected to the place.
content: I spent most of my life in Green Bay, Wis., cheering on the Packers, frequenting supper clubs and becoming a pro in winter wardrobe layering. I was a Wisconsinite through and through and would have been happy to stay there the rest of my life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: If the Pro-Life Movement Loses This One, Its Future Is in Danger
description: November’s second-most-important election is in Florida.
content: I’ll never forget the first time I heard my oldest daughter’s heartbeat. My wife was experiencing trouble in the first three months of pregnancy, and we were worried she was miscarrying. We rode together to her doctor’s office, full of anxiety. And then we heard the magical sound — the pulsing of our little girl’s tiny heart. We didn’t know if she would ultimately be OK, but there was one thing we knew: Our daughter was alive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim
title: Review: Philharmonic Pays Tribute to Schoenberg
description: The New York Philharmonic under Matthias Pintscher brought dramatic urgency to “Pelleas und Melisande” in commemoration of the composer’s 150th birthday.
content: When Arnold Schoenberg conducted the premiere of “Pelleas und Melisande,” his symphonic poem based on the somber fairy-tale that inspired Debussy’s opera, in 1905, it was in front of a hostile Viennese audience. Reviews were “unusually violent,” the composer would later recall, with one critic suggesting he be committed to an asylum and banned from all access to music paper.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Audra D. S. Burch, Eduardo Medina and Kate Selig
title: A Tale of Two Hurricanes Finds More That Differs Than Is the Same
description: Helene in North Carolina and Milton in Florida were very different storms in very different places.
content: Cindy Miller wasn’t sure where to begin the cleanup this weekend at her home in Englewood, Fla. Hurricane Milton had drenched her home and dumped debris everywhere. Much of it was not even hers. A sofa, doors and shoes littered the backyard, along with detritus that remained from Hurricane Helene, the deadliest hurricane to hit the U.S. mainland in nearly two decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: Friends With Benefits, but Without Illusions
description: In “Don’t Be a Stranger,” Susan Minot once again explores female desire, staging a romantic collision between a divorced mother and a much younger musician.
content: If you loved Miranda July’s “All Fours,” Knopf suggests, try Susan Minot’s “Don’t Be a Stranger.” How depressing. Minot is an O.G. writer of female desire who published the spare and potent “Lust and Other Stories” in 1989, when July was still in knee socks and Sally Rooney just a glimmer in Mr. Rooney’s eye. Its neon-lettered cover blazed from every cool girl’s bookshelf.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Nostrant
title: Texas Man Drops Suit Against Women Who Helped Ex-Wife Get Abortion Pills
description: The suit had accused the three women of wrongful death. It was part of a heated battle over the use of such pills in states with abortion bans.
content: A Texas man has dropped his lawsuit against three women who helped his ex-wife obtain abortion pills, a case widely seen as designed to discourage private citizens from aiding women in using the pills in states where abortion is all but banned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Silvio Berlusconi Died. But for Her, the ‘Bunga Bunga’ Scandal Lives On.
description: The woman at the center of revelations of bacchanals at the former Italian prime minister’s villa is still fighting a court case, and a negative public image, 14 years later.
content: Hardly a night goes by that Karima el-Mahroug does not think of what her life would be like if she had never met Silvio Berlusconi.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta
title: Monday Briefing: The U.S. to Deploy Troops to Israel
description: Plus, 200,000 stories of Modern Love.
content: The Pentagon said that it was sending an advanced missile defense system to Israel, along with about 100 American troops to operate it. It is the first deployment of U.S. forces to Israel since the Hamas-led attacks there on Oct. 7, 2023.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Samuel Faust
title: It’s OK if You Haven’t Gotten Your Flu Shot Yet
description: Public health agencies are pushing us to get flu vaccines too far ahead of the winter flu season.
content: Like many health care workers, I am required to receive my annual flu shot by the end of October. Every year, I wait until the last possible day to get vaccinated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Holmes
title: How Can I Get My Boss to Notice Me?
description: When there are men in the room, a female colleague is made to feel invisible.
content: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Niarchos
title: Christopher Steele and the Mueller Team Are Still Trying to Set the Record Straight
description: Two new books explore the messy business of uncovering Russian interference in American elections.
content: Why is it that this year’s election feels encrusted with such déjà vu? Is it the outsize presence of Nate Silver? Former President Donald Trump’s presence on the ticket? Or maybe it’s because Kremlin interference appears to have been ramping up in recent months. In September, the U.S. State Department announced it was pulling out all the stops, offering $10 million for information on a group called Russian Angry Hackers Did It.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer, Julie Bosman, Kellen Browning, Maya King and Jonathan Weisman
title: The Ground Game: Harris’s Turnout Machine vs. Trump’s Unproven Alliance
description: Both parties are frenetically chasing votes in the counties that could very well decide the election. In many places, inexperienced conservative groups are going up against a more tightly organized Democratic operation.
content: In the final weeks of the 2024 election, Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump are staking their chances on two radically different theories of how to win: one tried-and-true, the other untested in modern presidential campaigns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilma Wolitzer
title: The Author of ‘The Curious Incident’ Is Back With More Dogs
description: The new story collection by Mark Haddon takes inspiration from Greek myths, H.G. Wells and Snoopy.
content: The British writer Mark Haddon is best known for his 2003 novel “The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time,” in which a neurodivergent teenage boy solves a murder mystery and wins the reader’s heart. Haddon is equally accomplished at creating gripping narratives and sympathetic characters in his shorter fiction. The stories in this splendid new collection are inspired by an eclectic variety of sources, including a novel by H.G. Wells, Virginia Woolf’s first published story and, as with some of Haddon’s previous work, Greek mythology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: Ignore the Polls
description: They can’t tell you what you want to know.
content: Here’s a bit of advice to help maintain your sanity over the next few weeks until Election Day: Just ignore the polls. Unless you’re a campaign professional or a gambler, you’re probably looking at them for the same reason the rest of us are: to know who’ll win. Or at least to feel like you know who’ll win. But they just can’t tell you that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa and Nicholas Nehamas
title: On the Trail, Harris Turns to Her Experience Fighting Cross-Border Crime
description: As California’s attorney general, Kamala Harris prioritized the fight against traffickers of drugs and people. It’s a part of her biography she hasn’t always talked about.
content: As Vice President Kamala Harris vows to crack down on illegal immigration at the nation’s southern border, she has played up her experience as California’s attorney general pursuing criminal groups that traffic drugs, guns and people across the United States and Mexico.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘We Would Take the Bus to Her Home on East 37th Street After School’
description: Remembering a best friend, packed into a subway car and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: After Helene, Bradenton Beach Residents Left Town for Milton
description: Quotation of the Day for October 13, 2024.
content: “I told him, ‘Bev’s house is headed your way.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Raftery
title: A Day in the Life of Tim Heidecker, Glendale Dad
description: Years after making his name with the sketch comedy series “Tim and Eric Awesome Show, Great Job!”, he’s singing wry ballads and watching the kids.
content: From the moment he showed up at Tim Heidecker’s house, the Chihuahua in the dragon costume seemed a little freaked out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: A Birth Scene So Taxing, Andrew Garfield and Florence Pugh Needed to Rest
description: The stars and director of “We Live in Time” explain how a delivery became an action sequence, complete with a real baby and a few unwelcome surprises.
content: You wouldn’t expect the romantic drama “We Live in Time” to have an action scene, but it does — at least that’s how Andrew Garfield sees it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Why Is Trump Gaining With Black and Hispanic Voters?
description: Five possible explanations for the increases in support, particularly among young men.
content: In 2016, Donald J. Trump became the Republican nominee and ultimately won the presidency after calling many Mexican immigrants rapists and falsely claiming that Barack Obama was not born in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

title: I Write My Obituary, So I Can Live a Better Life
description: Readers offer their personal stories in response to a guest essay. Also: Trump and baseball; G.O.P. mirage machine; S.N.L. and Gerald Ford; unforeseen crises.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Shaw
title: Lawyers Should Not Assist Trump in a Potential Power Grab
description: Lawyers should remember what they were taught in ethics class.
content: As the presidential campaign begins its final sprint, Donald Trump has made crystal clear how he will respond if he loses. He will refuse to accept the results; he will make baseless claims of voter fraud; and he will turn, with even more ferocity than he did in 2020, to the courts to save him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Democrats to Fly Harris Ads Over N.F.L. Games in Swing States
description: Fans at games in four swing states will see skywriting or banners over their stadium on Sunday. The vice president’s campaign would like men in particular to look up.
content: As the Harris campaign continues to court male voters, it is dialing up a deep shot, targeting a venue where it thinks it will reach quite a few of them: professional football.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Knight
title: Once Known for Death Row, San Quentin Hosts a Star-Studded Film Festival
description: The California prison used to house some of the state’s most violent criminals, but has become more known lately for creative pursuits.
content: The prizes were paper certificates. The red carpet measured just a few feet long. The catered lunch spread was state-issued bologna sandwiches wrapped in plastic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: ‘Saturday Night Live’ and the Underappreciated Influence of Carol Burnett
description: A new film about the show doesn’t mention her. But in many ways her hit sketch series helped define the early vision of Lorne Michaels.
content: What makes Lorne Michaels laugh?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden Calls for Bipartisan Effort to Help Areas Hit by Storms
description: The president surveyed damage in Florida and announced $612 million for projects to help the electric grid in areas affected by Hurricanes Helene and Milton.
content: Standing in front of one of the many houses wrecked by Hurricane Milton in Florida, President Biden said on Sunday that the storm was devastating for those who lost homes, businesses or relatives, even as he expressed relief that the storm was not as destructive as anticipated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Kelly
title: A Hedgehog, a Centrifuge and Other Millennial Life-Improvement Splurges
description: Placing a high value on personal growth, millennials and Gen Z appear more likely than older generations to make hobbies and nonessential purchases a spending priority.
content: How much ongoing joy can you get from something that weighs eight ounces?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Aaron Boxerman, Johnatan Reiss and Thomas Fuller
title: Hezbollah Drone Strike Kills 4 Israeli Soldiers on Military Base
description: The strike, which wounded dozens, showed that the militant group remains a force.
content: A drone strike by Hezbollah on a military base in the north of Israel killed four soldiers and wounded dozens of other people, the Israeli military said Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton
title: F.A.A. Clears the Way for SpaceX to Hold Starship Launch on Sunday
description: The agency said the company had agreed to study the environmental impact of its launches in South Texas and ways to mitigate harm to wildlife.
content: The Federal Aviation Administration issued a new license on Saturday allowing Elon Musk’s SpaceX company to launch its Starship rocket again from South Texas, and it included new requirements to limit the harm to birds’ nests and other wildlife in an adjacent state park and National Wildlife Refuge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Dunlap
title: A Test of Knowledge and a Winning Entrant
description: Can you guess which former New York Times critic won the newspaper’s intercollegiate contest as a student?
content: “Did you follow the news this week?” That’s how The New York Times News Quiz announces itself each weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Kuo
title: Filmed in New York, Hold the Taxis and Radiators
description: When independent movies like “Rosemead” travel to a state for tax incentives, they save money but add creative challenges.
content: On a rainy morning this past January, Roosevelt Avenue in the Flushing neighborhood of Queens was a stream of yellow cabs, honking buses and weaving cyclists. Nearby, a film crew peering out the windows of a Chinese pharmacy discussed how to make all of that invisible.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Cross-Tabs: October 2024 Times/Siena Poll of the Hispanic Likely Electorate
description: Results of a nationwide New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 902 Hispanic voters from Sept. 29 to Oct. 6, 2024.
content: Results of a nationwide New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 902 Hispanic voters from Sept. 29 to Oct. 6, 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard, Sergey Ponomarev, Leanne Abraham and Marco Hernandez
title: Roadblocked
description: How you can get around the West Bank depends on who you are. We took two bus trips, one with Palestinians and one with Israelis, that tell a story of separate and unequal roadways.
content: How you can get around the West Bank depends on who you are. We took two bus trips, one with Palestinians and one with Israelis, that tell a story of separate and unequal roadways.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Cross-Tabs: October 2024 Times/Siena Poll of Hispanic Registered Voters
description: Results of a nationwide New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 902 Hispanic voters from Sept. 29 to Oct. 6, 2024.
content: Results of a nationwide New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 902 Hispanic voters from Sept. 29 to Oct. 6, 2024.

author: By McKinnon de Kuyper
title: SpaceX Achieves Its First-Ever ‘Chopsticks’ Landing
description: SpaceX launched and returned a large rocket booster to its Texas site, catching it with mechanical arms in its first-ever “chopsticks” landing.
content: SpaceX launched and returned a large rocket booster to its Texas site, catching it with mechanical arms in its first-ever “chopsticks” landing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Igielnik, Gabriel Blanco, Karen Hanley and Laura Salaberry
title: GOP Is Making Inroads With Black and Hispanic Voters
description: Former President Donald J. Trump has gained some ground since 2020 among Black and Hispanic voters, especially men. Ruth Igielnik, who conducts polls for The New York Times, explains.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump has gained some ground since 2020 among Black and Hispanic voters, especially men. Ruth Igielnik, who conducts polls for The New York Times, explains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard, Rebecca Suner and James Surdam
title: How Palestinians Are Roadblocked in the West Bank
description: Driving in the Israeli-occupied West Bank is an incredibly different experience depending on who you are. Ben Hubbard, international correspondent for The New York Times, rode along on two bus trips, one for Israelis, the other for Palestinians, that tell a story of separate and unequal roadways.
content: Driving in the Israeli-occupied West Bank is an incredibly different experience depending on who you are. Ben Hubbard, international correspondent for The New York Times, rode along on two bus trips, one for Israelis, the other for Palestinians, that tell a story of separate and unequal roadways.
source.name: The New York Times
